reviewText: Another great double feature starring the great Tim McCoy, both movies are great to watch with all the action one usually expects from Tim.

Poverty Row Pictures presents "OUTLAW DEPUTY/WEST OF RAINBOW'S END" (1935/38) (116 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) --- The American actor Tim McCoy in real life was a sharpshooter and famed for his fast draw --- The Native Americans had no better ambassador than Tim McCoy, a former Indian language translator in real life --- Tim McCoy spoke passionately about this country's longtime abuse of its native population by breaking treaty after treaty --- McCoy an expert on the Old West, also an authority on Indian folklore could converse in Indian sign language --- McCoy was inducted into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1973, also inducted into "The Cowboy Hall of Fame" in 1974.

The first film of this double feature - "THE OUTLAW DEPUTY" (20 June 1935) (59 mins/B&W)

Under the production staff of:
Otto Brower  - Director
Nat Ross  - Producer
Del Andrews  - Screenwriter
Ford I. Beebe  - Screenwriter
James Diamond  - Cinematographer
Robert Johns  - Editor
Johnston McCulley  - Short Story Author

The story line and plot, our hero 'Steely Eyed' Tim McCoy is in another poverty row quickie western --- this was the first in a series of Tim McCoy films for Puritan Pictures of Poverty Row, there were ten films in all...veteran character actor Bud Osborne is locking horns with Tim McCoy over a robbery and the killing of his friend George Offerman Jr...can McCoy find the killer and at the same time become a deputy who has a shady past that may just catch up to him...what does Offerman's watch have to do with anything, can McCoy prove whoever has it may be the killer....Hooper Atchley the boss of Goldland has never met his match but there is a first time for everything...in one scene Atchley walks up to McCoy and gives him a piece of his mind, McCoy answers with another challenge turns his back and walks out of the saloon...another badman wants to know why he didn't plug McCoy when he turned his back...Atchley replies, McCoy has nerve, I could never shoot a man like that in the back...will McCoy bring Atchley to justice and wind up with the heroine Nora Lane, or will he ride off into the sunset and never look back.

the cast includes:
Tim McCoy ...  Tim Mallory
 Nora Lane ...  Joyce Rutledge
 Hooper Atchley ...  Howger
 Joseph W. Girard ...  Ed Rutledge (as Joe Girrard)
 George Offerman Jr. ...  Chuck Adams
 Bud Osborne ...  Cash (as Bud Osborn)
 Charles Brinley ...  Henchman Draige
 Jack Montgomery ...  Henchman Stibes
 George Holt ...  Crentz (Saloon Owner)
 Si Jenks ...  Charlie (Hotel Owner) (as Cy Jenks)

Second film of the this double feature - "WEST OF RAINBOW'S END" (12 January 1938) (57 mins/B&W)

Under the production staff of:
Alan James  - Director
Maurice Conn  - Producer
Stanley Roberts  - Screenwriter
Robert Emmett Tansey  - Screenwriter
John H. Greenhalgh, Jr.  - Cinematographer
Connie Lee  - Composer (Music Score)

The story line and plot, our hero 'Steely Eyed' Tim McCoy is in another poverty row quickie western --- Tim Hart (Tim McCoy) arrives looking for the killer of his friend Lightning Ed. Johnson (Frank LaRue) is behind the murder as he wants to buy the Carter ranch cheap so he can sell it to the railroad at a big profit. When Tim steps in to take over for Lightning Ed, Johnson and his gang make plans to finish him off.

the cast includes:
  Tim McCoy ...  Tim Hart
 Kathleen Eliot ...  Joan Carter (as Kathleen Elliott)
 Walter McGrail ...  Johnson
 George Cooper ...  Happy
 Mary Carr ...  Martha Carter
 Bob Kortman ...  Henchman Speck
 Hank Bell ...  Henchman
 Frank LaRue ...  Lightning Ed
 Reed Howes ...  Ted Crane
 Edward Coxen ...  Joel Carter (as Ed Coxen)
 Jimmy Aubrey ...  Postmaster
 George Chang ...  Elmer

BIOS:
1. Tim McCoy (aka: Timothy John Fitzgerald McCoy)
Birth Date: 4/10/1891 - Saginaw, Michigan
Died: 1/29/1978 - Nogales, Arizona

If you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure check out other western double features --- Ask Amazon. Com to carry the volumes as they are not available on Amazon as of yet --- you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment

TIM McCOY WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURES - VCI Entertainment:
Vol 1: End of the Trail & Lightning Carson Rides Again
Vol 2: Code of the Cactus & Fighting Renegade
Vol 3: Bulldog Courage & Ghost Patrol
Vol 4: Roarin' Guns & The Traitor
Vol 5: Trigger Fingers & Phantom Ranger
Vol 6: Fighting Shadows & Justice of the Range
Vol 7: Cornered & Daring Danger
Vol 8: Six Gun Trail & Prescott Kid
Vol 9: Riding Tornado & Riding Wild

Also available from VCI Entertaiment:
ROUGH RIDERS WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURE (Tim McCoy, Buck Jones and Raymond Hatton)
Vol 1: Arizona Bound & Gunman From Bodie
Vol 2: Ghost Town Law & Below the Border
Vol 3: Forbidden Trails & Down Texas Way

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- If you're into the memories of B-Westerns with high drama, this is the one you've been anxiously waiting for --- please stand up and take a bow --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 116 min on VHS/DVD ~ Poverty Row Pictures ~ (7/25/2006)
